findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop transactions for all users excluding the owner by setting certain parameters (minSellTransactionAmount, maxSellTransactionAmount, handleLimitTime) that can limit users from selling more than 20% of the circulating supply.

findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to massively stop addresses from transactions. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `blackListMultipleAddresses` function.

findings.title: DTA - Dividend Tracker Architecture
findings.description: The DIVIDEND_TRACKER role has the authority to mint the rewarded amount of a private investor’s unlocked investment to its account’s balance.

findings.title: SCP - Solidity Code Principles
findings.description: Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: US - Untrusted Source
findings.description: The contract uses an external contract to determine the transaction's flow, which can lead to inconsistency in transactions if the owner's account is compromised and the external contract is set to an untrusted source.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases unnecessarily the gas consumption since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert on underflow and overflow.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not follow the Solidity naming convention guidelines, which can decrease readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can occur due to conditional statements that are always false, functions that are never called, or unreachable code, making a contract more difficult to understand and maintain.
